huntMaster.SPECIAL_INSTRUCTIONS: Permit holders may pursue, but not take cougars.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by the BLM.  There is a significant amount of SITLA land.  There are several DWR Wildlife Management Areas (WMA).  These areas are managed for wildlife and you can hunt on all these areas.  There is private land and some of it is accessible through the DWR’s Walk-in-Access Program (http://wildlife.utah.gov/walkinaccess/).
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: :  Meadow Creek, Two Waters, Bitter Creek, Willow Creek, and Little Creek.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
Please direct all questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Vernal BLM Field Office (http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html)
BLM:  14 day camping limit and you have to move 30 miles after 14 days.
DWR WMA’S:  There is a 14 day limit on WMA’s, and there is no camping on the Willow Creek WMA.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
There are several access points to the Book Cliffs.  From the north side there are two main roads that take you to the Book Cliffs.  Utah State Road 88 located between Vernal and Roosevelt.  As you follow it south it turns into the Seep Ridge Road.  Hwy 45 or the Bonanza Hwy is located east of Vernal.  It takes you towards the east side of the Book Cliffs.  After you cross the White River you come to the Dragon or Duck Rock intersection.  The Dragon Rd will take you south to the Book Cliffs.

The Hay Canyon Rd is the main access road on the south side of the Book Cliffs.  You can access it from I-70.  It is a hard packed dirt/gravel road.  

The roadless area has two access points, a north and a south.  The north access is called the Ten Mile Knoll trailhead.  It is located at the start of Steer Ridge.  There is a parking area, but it can fill up in a hurry with trucks and horse trailers.  The south trailhead starts at the top of Sego Canyon.  The road starts at Thompson Springs in Grand County and continues up the Sego Canyon Rd; follow it to the end of the road.  There is a water trough at the trailhead, but it is not always full of water.  This trailhead can also fill up with vehicles, and trailers.  There are no bathrooms or other facilities at either of these trailheads, so plan accordingly.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: Contact BLM Field Office.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, SITLA, and DWR, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Vernal BLM Field Office, and SITLA.  The DWR WMA’s are restricted to ATV and vehicle travel on established roads and trails.   

Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads.  There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.  

The Book Cliffs offers a challenging landscape.  There are large ridges with steep canyons dividing them.  Most of the canyons and ridges have roads or ATV trails to provide access.  There are plenty of areas to hike and get away from the main roads.  The hunting pressure will drastically decrease after opening weekend.  

There are two roads that allow you to drive across the majority of the Book Cliffs.  The Kings Well Rd starts at the Seep Ridge Rd on the west side, and it can take you all the way to the Dragon Rd on the east side.  The Indian Ridge Road starts at the Seep Ridge Rd and goes through the bottom of Sweet Water, top of McCook Ridge, Bitter Creek, and to Big Park.  It is a great road to locate cougars during this time of year.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The boundary excludes all of the Tribal Trust Lands.  There is a large area of Ute Tribal Trust land to the west of the hunt unit.  Road access across the Tribal land is permitted using county roads.  All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands; they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal lands.  

There are some private ranches that post their property.  There are also privately owned lands that allow access through the DWR Walk-in-Access Program.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by the BLM. The National Park Service manages Glen Canyon National Recreation Area and Horse Shoe National Park. These areas are interspersed with SITLA land. There is is also private land on Mt. Ellen, Mt. Hillers, and leased land on Mt. Holmes.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: There are no DWR Wildlife Management Areas
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: There are three managed campgrounds on the Henry Mtns. Two on Mt Ellen: Lonesome Beaver and McMillan, and Mt. Hillers: Star Springs. Direct questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Hanksville BLM Field Office. http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/richfield/recreation_/henry_mountains.html
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
Deer, Bison, Elk: There are several Henry Mountain access roads. Mount Ellen can be accessed on the North from the Sawmill Basin road, travel south on 100 East in Hanksville. Access to the east side of Mt Ellen is from the Little Egypt road at mile marker 20 off of SR95. Access to the west side of Ellen and Pennell is off the Notom/Burr Trail road, turn east at the Sandy Ranch. The east side of Mount Pennell and the north side of Mount Hillers can be accessed from the Coyote Benches/Stanton Pass road off of SR276. The east and south side of Mount Hillers can be accessed from the Star Springs road also off of SR276. All these roads connect with each other so there is general access to various areas across the mountain range.The BLM has put up good signage to get you around.

Desert Bighorn Sheep: Some of the best access is from Lake Powell on the east side of the unit. From the lake you can access Trachyte, Two Mile, Four Mile, Peshliki, and Ticaboo drainages. SR95 through North Wash follows along the North side of the unit and hwy 276 which travels along the west side of Mt. Holmes and Elsworth and the east side Mt. Hillers. From the map you will see a few stem roads going east off of SR276. One accesses Trachyte Point for about 3 miles where it ends above Hog Springs. Another road stems towards Mt. Holmes and Fred Ridge but this soon dead ends at a private property gate. Another road stems also to Mt. Ellsworth. Ticaboo Mesa is also accessed from SR276, this road runs along the southern side of Mt. Ellsworth and overlooks the canyon forks of Ticaboo Creek and other canyons and mesas to the North.

Roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, Wayne and Garfield counties, and SITLA, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans. The Cave Flat road has a temporary closure November 1st – May 15th. Direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Hanksville BLM Field Office, SITLA, and the county you are traveling. http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/richfield/recreation_/henry_mountains.html

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The boundary excludes all of the Capital Reef National Park (CRNP). CRNP strictly regulates all hunting activity and access through the Park which is limited to the Swap Canyon trail on foot or by horse. At the end of the Cow Bison Orientation is detailed information about bison hunting and CRNP. You can see the orientation here. Contact Capital Reef National park for more information. http://www.nps.gov/care/contacts.htm

There is private property on both Mount Ellen and Mount Hillers. Mount Holmes also has private leased property. Written permission from the landowner/lessee is required by law to access and hunt private land.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: 65% public land.  Public, Private and Tribal Lands.  The public lands are all US Forest Service lands managed by the Ashley National Forest.  The Tribal lands are mostly the lower elevation sagebrush areas.  There is a large amount of private property on the unit too.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Mail Draw, Marshall Draw, Warren Draw, Little Hole, Browns Park
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and BLM. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the public lands. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
South Slope: http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/ashley/home

huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service or BLM and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service.
Ashley National Forest: http://www.fs.usda.gov/detail/ashley/home/?cid=STELPRDB5432815
BLM: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There are Tribal lands and private property included within this hunt boundary.  Hunting is not allowed on Ute Tribal lands.  Hunters should receive written permission before hunting on private property.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Daggett and Uintah counties—Boundary begins at the Green River and the Utah-Colorado state line; west along the Green River to Flaming Gorge Reservoir; west along the south shoreline of Flaming Gorge Reservoir to Cart Creek; south along this creek to US-191; south on US-191 to the Uintah/Daggett county line (summit of the Uinta Mountains); west along this summit to the Dry Fork-Whiterocks drainage divide;  southwest along the divide to USFS Trail #025 and Whiterocks Lake; south along the lake and trail to the East Fork of the Whiterocks River;  south along this river to the Whiterocks river; south along this river to the Uinta River; south along this river to the Duchesne River; south along this river to the Green River; south along this river to the White River; east along this river to the Utah-Colorado state line; north on this state line to the Green River. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Dutch John, Seep Ridge, Vernal. Boundary questions? Call the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.

huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Box Elder, Cache, Morgan and Weber counties—Boundary begins at US-91 and SR-101 west of Hyrum; east on SR-101 to Hardware Ranch and USFS Road 054 (Ant Flat Road); south on this road to SR-39; southwest on SR-39 to SR-167 (Trappers Loop Road); south on SR-167 to I-84 (Exit 92); west on I-84 to I-15; north on I-15 to US-91; northeast on US-91 to SR-101 west of Hyrum. This hunt is comprised of all or largely private property. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Logan, Ogden, Promontory Point. Boundary questions? Call the Ogden office, 801-476-2740.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public lands are all Forest Service lands managed by the Ashley and Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forests.  This unit includes a large portion of the High Uintas Wilderness Area where all motor vehicles are prohibited.  This unit also includes large tracts of Ute tribal lands that are closed to non-tribal members.  The tribal lands are mostly the lower elevation sagebrush zone but in some areas they reach up into the aspen/conifer zone.  There is a large amount of private property on the unit too.  Most of the private property is below the tribal boundary but there are several parcels of private property in the canyon bottoms.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Little Montes Creek WMA north of Ballard and Kevin Conway WMA southeast of Myton.  Elk, bear and cougar are rarely found on these WMAs.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All Campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the forest. There are special restrictions on camping and campfires in certain areas within the Wilderness area. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
Ashley National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The main access points for the High Uintas Wilderness include: Uinta Canyon Trailhead, West Fork of Whiterocks Trailhead, Chepeta Trailhead, Lake Fork Trailhead, Yellowstone/Swift Creek Trailhead, Jackson Park road, Dry Gulch road, Rock Creek Trailhead, North Fork of Duchesne Trailhead, and Grandview trailheads
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Kings Peak and Duchesne topo maps
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. Maps can also be purchased online at:http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The hunt unit does not include the Ute tribal lands.  There is a large tract of Ute tribal trust land that stretches east to west across the South Slope of the Uinta Mountains.  Road access across the tribal land is permitted only across the main access roads to the Forest.  All ATVs are prohibited on tribal Lands, they must be trailered on access roads across tribal Lands.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Duchesne, Summit, Uintah and Wasatch counties—Boundary begins at SR-87 and US-40 in Duchesne; north on SR-87 to SR-35; northwest on SR-35 to the Provo River; north along this river to North Fork Provo River; north along this river to SR-150; east and north on SR-150 to the Summit-Duchesne county line (summit of the Uinta Mountains) at Hayden Pass; east along the summit of the Uinta Mountains to the Dry Fork-Whiterocks drainage divide; south atop this divide to USFS Trail #025; southwest on this trail to Whiterocks Lake and the East Fork of the Whiterocks River; south along this river to the Whiterocks River; south along this river to the Uinta River; south along this river to the Duchesne River; west along this river to US-40 at Myton; west on US-40 to SR-87 in Duchesne. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Duchesne, Dutch John, Kings Peak, Provo, Salt Lake City, Vernal. Boundary questions? Call the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by USFS, BLM and private ownership. The northeast portion of the Oquirrh Mountains is privately owned (Rio Tinto-Kennecott) and is a CWMU. Hunters should become familiar with the property boundary.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Pine Canyon and Walt Fitzgerald WMAs
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
There are many dispersed camping sites within this unit, and developed campgrounds in North and South Willow Canyons, Grantsville Reservoir, Middle Canyon, Settlement Canyon and Ophir Canyon.
Bureau of Land Management: Please direct all questions regarding roads, maps and camping to the BLM Salt Lake Field Office https://www.blm.gov/office/salt-lake-field-office or (801) 320-8300

Forest Service: Please direct all questions regarding roads, maps and camping to the USFS Salt Lake Ranger district http://www.fs.fed.us or (801) 733-2660
There is no camping allowed on DWR WMA’s in this area.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: Highways 73, 36, 199, Mormon Trail Road, Skull Valley Road, Butterfield Canyon Road, and West Canyon
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: BLM 1:100,000 Scale Maps: Rush Valley, Tooele
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Generally, there is good ATV access on this unit. Please contact the USFS or BLM for the latest on ATV access.
Tooele County has information on county trails

http://www.tooelecountytrails.com/trails_map.html
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: All Tribal Lands are excluded from this hunt unit. The Skull Valley Goshute Tribe does not allow hunters across tribal lands to access Forest Service or BLM lands. Hunting on military lands (e.g. Tooele Army Depot North and South) is not permitted.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Salt Lake, Tooele and Utah counties--Boundary begins at I-15 and I-80 in Salt Lake City; south on I-15 to SR-73; west on SR-73 to Pony Express Road; west on this road to Faust Junction and SR-36; south on SR-36 to Pony Express Road; west on this road to the Skull Valley road; north on this road to I-80 at Rowley Junction; east on I-80 to I-15. The Pine Springs Conservation Wildlife Management Area is closed to motorized travel year-round. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Provo, Rush Valley, Salt Lake City, Tooele. Boundary questions? Call the Springville office, (801) 491-5678.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public, State Trust Lands (SITLA), Private and Utah Division of Wildlife Resources (DWR) Lands.  The public lands are Bureau of Land Management (BLM) managed out of the Cedar City Field Office.  This unit also includes over 10,000 acres of Division of Wildlife Resources land specifically for the benefit of wildlife and our sportsmen.  There is one CWMU on the unit (Zane) for pronghorn and one Landowners Association for elk.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: The Indian Peaks Wildlife Management area is good habitat for Elk and Deer.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: There are no official campgrounds on this unit. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the BLM. Cedar City and Fillmore BLM website: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/cedar_city/recreation.html http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/fillmore/recreation.html
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: BLM 1:100,000 maps Cedar City, South Wah Wah, North Wah Wah
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: Private landowners have had several issues with trespass by hunters in recent years. Please respect private property, fences, livestock presence and close gates.  County Sheriffs Deputies and DWR wildlife officers will be out patrolling during the hunting seasons.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Beaver, Iron and Millard counties—Boundary begins at the Utah-Nevada state line and US-6/50; east on US-6/50 to SR-257; south on SR-257 to SR-21; south on SR-21 to SR-130; south on SR-130 to I-15; south on I-15 to SR-56; west on SR-56 to the Lund highway; northwest on this highway to Lund and the Union Pacific railroad tracks; southwest along these tracks to the Utah-Nevada state line; north on this state line to US-6/50. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Beaver, Caliente, Cedar City, Delta, Garrison, Richfield, Tule Valley, Wah Wah Mountains North, Wah Wah Mountains South, Wilson Creek Range. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Some private does exist make sure to check map for accurate details
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Multiple campground and wilderness camps are available.  Popular areas to camp can be found as you go west from the Sulpherdale exit.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
Access to the unit can be found all around. Several access points east of I-15 include:
Big Johns Flat- Plenty of Access and camping
Big Flat- Plenty of access and camping
Kents Lake- Popular camping area must hike off the road to get away from people
Rainbow Mine- Limited road access
Cottonwood Creek- limited road access
City Creek Peak- limited road access, popular area
Lebaron Reservoir- limited road access, popular area
Mumford Reservoir– Limited access, steep areas
Bakers Canyon- popular area
Briggs Ridge– remote hunting area, steep terrain
Shingle Creek Meadows- Some ATV trails and remote hunting opportunities.
North Creek– Limited Access
Manderfield- gravel roads, a little flatter area, be aware of private Property
Main access points west of I-15 are out of Beaver, Milford, Sulpherdale, and the Black Rock Road.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: Fishlake National Forest map for the Beaver and Fillmore Ranger Districts
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: See Map
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: Although plentiful public land exists on the Beaver there is some private spread throughout the unit.  See Map for specific details.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Beaver, Garfield, Iron, Millard, Piute and Sevier counties—Boundary begins at SR-130 and I-15; north on SR-130 to SR-21; north on SR-21 to SR-257; north on SR-257 to Black Rock Road; east on this road to I-15; south on I-15 to I-70; east on I-70 to US-89; south on US-89 to SR-20; west on SR-20 to I-15; south on I-15 to SR-130. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Beaver, Cedar City, Panguitch, Richfield. Boundary Questions?  Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public, Private and Tribal Lands.  Public lands include lands managed by the BLM, USFS (Fish Lake National Forest), and the state of Utah.  Most of the mountainous ground is public land and open to the public. There are both large and small tracts of privately owned property scattered both in the low country and high country. In addition there is a small parcel of tribal land adjacent to Koosharem reservoir
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Elbow Ranch WMA - The Elbow Ranch WMA is a large winter range area. Do not expect high numbers of big game or bears to use this area during most hunting seasons.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: There is only one official campground located on the unit. This campground is owned by the Koosharem Band of Piutes and is located adjacent to Koosharem reservoir. Hotel/camping accommodations exist in cities and towns that surround the unit. There is also a nearby campground at Otter Creek State Park. Camping outside of official campgrounds is permitted on most public ground. Please direct camping questions to the appropriate land management agency. Fishlake National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/fishlake
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: There are several main access roads to the Monroe unit. You can access the north side via road #068 from either the town of Annabella or Glenwood. This is a well maintained gravel road. From the east side you can take road #076 out of Koosharem and #069 out of Greenwich. Road #069 is the best road to take if you are pulling camp a trailer. The south end of the mountain can be accessed with the Pole canyon road (#072) near Angle or the Monroe Mountain road (#068) near Kingston. Both of these are maintained but are rather narrow and not recommended for large trailers. To access the west side of the unit use the Dry Creek road (#071) or the Monroe Canyon road (#078). Both of these roads are not recommended for trailers.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Beaver, Loa, Richfield, Salina.  USFS Travel Management map
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: ATV and Vehicle Access: The Monroe unit has an extensive road and trail system. Many good areas to hunt can be accessed via vehicle. During the early hunting seasons most all roads and trails can be accessed. During later seasons early and heavy snows may make travel difficult. Some trails are restricted to ATVs of a certain size only. Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. Maps can also be purchased online at: http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/fishlake/maps-pubs
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There are both large and small tracts of privately owned property scattered both in the low elevation and high areas. In addition there is a small parcel of tribal land adjacent to Koosharem reservoir. Please respect all private lands and associated trespass laws.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Piute and Sevier counties—Boundary begins at US-89 and I-70 near Sevier; south on US-89 to SR-62; east and north on SR-62 to SR-24; north on SR-24 to I-70; south on I-70 to US-89 near Sevier. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Beaver, Loa, Richfield, Salina. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Forest Service, BLM, State, Private
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Kingston Canyon WMA is on the north end and has sportsman access, but it is all on foot.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: No campgrounds are located on the unit but dispersed camping is available.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: You can access the south end of the unit from the Tom Best Spring road off of HWY 12. You can access the east side of the unit on several different access point along SR-22 (John's Valley Highway). The north end of the unit is inaccessible except by foot. The west side of the unit can be accessed by several points from Circleville to Panguitch along HWY 89. I would access the top of the mountain using the Jones Corral or Cottonwood loop road.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USFS, and BLM land maps.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: ATV's are a good way to access the units. Several roads are impassible by vehicle so an ATV would be recommended.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Garfield and Piute counties—Boundary begins at US-89 and SR-62; south on US-89 to SR-12; east on SR-12 to the Widtsoe-Antimony Road; north on this road to SR-22; north on SR-22 to SR-62; west on SR-62 to US-89. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Beaver, Escalante, Loa, Panguitch. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: BLM, USFS, SITLA with some private parcels scattered throughout the unit.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Please refer all campground questions to the appropriate land management agency. Fish Lake and Dixie National Forest, Richfield and Loa offices. BLM offices are in Richfield.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: SR-72 near Loa and Torrey
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Loa, Salina.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
There is an expansive road and trail system on this unit. All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and USFS. Most Travel regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated to the Fish Lake and Dixie National Forest, Richfield and Loa offices. BLM offices are in Richfield and Escalante. The USFS has a travel map that covers most of this area. 
http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/fishlake/maps-pubs
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Sevier and Wayne counties—Boundary begins at the junction of SR-24 and SR-72; east on SR-24 to the Caineville Wash road; north along the Caineville Wash road to the Cathedral Valley road; west on the Cathedral Valley road to Rock Springs Bench and the Last Chance Desert road; north on the Last Chance Desert road to the Blue Flats road; north and east on the Blue Flats road to the Willow Springs road; north on the Willow Springs road towards Windy Peak and the Windy Peak road; west on the Windy Peak road to SR-72; south on SR-72 to SR-24. Private lands within this boundary are open to general deer hunting. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Salina, San Rafael Desert, Loa, Hanksville. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of the land within the unit is owned by the USFS and the BLM and is open to the public. There are some large tracts of private land, many of which are enrolled in the CWMU program and you must possess a valid CWMU permit to hunt big game there. Permission by landowner may be granted by to hunt cougars on the CWMUs
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
There are many improved Camping areas on the Fish Lake unit, both public and private. Good camping exists in Gooseberry area, Elk Horn, multiple areas around Fish Lake and Johnson Reservoir. Primitive camping is allowed on much of the BLM and USFS managed lands. There is one improved campground managed by the Piute tribe near Koosharem reservoir. Contact the managing agency for detailed information. http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/richfield.html
http://www.fs.usda.gov/activity/fishlake/recreation/camping-cabins
http://www.recreation.gov/unifSearchResults.do
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: There are many ways to access this unit. The north end can be accessed off of I-70 at the Gooseberry exit and also at the Hwy 72 exit. There are also many smaller unimproved roads that get you into good country from the frontage road along I-70. Access to the eastern side of the unit is via hwy 72. Roads that fork from hwy 72 that get you into good county include the Last Chance road, Road #206 that gets you onto the Thousand Lake Mountain, road #036 that takes you past Mill Meadow Reservoir and to Fish Lake.  There are many ATV trails and smaller unimproved roads that fork off of Hwy 72. The main access on the south end is SR-25 to Fish Lake via SR-24.   The west side is accessed via several dirt roads including the Hancock Flat road off of SR-25,  Road #053 that forks off of SR-24 gets you into the Rex Reservoir, and the Lost Creek country.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Maps Loa, Salina.  USFS Travel Management Map
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: There is an expansive road and trail system on this unit. All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, USFS, Sevier and Wayne counties. Most travel regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated to the Fish Lake National Forest, Richfield and Loa offices. BLM offices are in Richfield and Loa. The USFS has a travel map that covers most of this area.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: Private/Tribal Lands issues: There are several large tracts of private property on this unit. Several of these tracts are enrolled in the CWMU program and require special permits to hunt on them. Consult a good map to ensure you know where you are and to avoid any trespass conflicts
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Piute, Sevier and Wayne counties—Boundary begins at SR-24 and SR-72; west and north on SR-24 to I-70; east on I-70 to SR-72; south on SR-72 to SR-24. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps:  Loa, Salina. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: Bear Valley on hwy 20. Also several Forest Service and BLM access roads off of highway 143 between Cedar Breaks and Panguitch.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The large majority of land that is currently occupied by sheep is managed by either USFS or BLM.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
Oak Creek Canyon has a campground with limited space. Please check with the BLM and USFS for more information on public land camping.
Hotel lodging can be found in Delta, Fillmore, and Scipio.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
Oak Creek Canyon has a good road that can be accessed with a truck for the majority of the year. There is a USFS gate near the mouth of the canyon that can be closed during different times of the year. Please check with the Fillmore, UT USFS office for current road information.
Dry Creek has a good road that can handle a truck but is more enjoyable on an ATV. On the East side of the range there are roads that can be accessed via truck or ATV. Most of the roads on the east side dead end at the mouths of canyons and don't go far into the mountain range. Please plan ahead with a map and only drive on designated roads.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Juab, Millard, Sanpete and Sevier counties—Boundary begins at Black Rock Road and I-15(Exit 135); west on Black Rock Road to SR-257; north on SR-257 to US-6/50; east on US-6/50 to US-6; northeast on US-6 to Santaquin and I-15; south on I-15 to Exit 135 and Black Rock Road. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Duchesne, Nephi, Price. Boundary questions? Call Vernal office, 435-781-9453.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public, Private and Parks Service.  The public lands are primarily US Forest Service lands managed by the Manti-La Sal National Forest and The Bureau of Land Management(BLM) managed out of the Moab Field Office.  This unit also includes National Parks Service lands that are closed to hunting.  The private lands are primarily on the Eastern portion of the unit, but there are private lands scattered throughout the unit. There are two CWMU's on the unit (Redd Ranches and JB Ranch).
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All Campgrounds on this subunit are managed by the US Forest Service, Utah State Institutional Trust Lands and the Bureau of Land Management. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the Forest. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service, SITLA or the BLM. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
USFS: http://www.fs.usda.gov/mantilasal

BLM: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/prog/recreation_home/activities/camping.html

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The vast majority of the unit is public land.  The exception is the Green River Valley near the town of Green River
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: There are no developed campgrounds on the unit.  Plenty of dispersed camping opportunities exist on BLM lands.  Most people camp along the lower Price River east of Woodside, along the Green River north of the town of Green River or in Tushar Canyon
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The Horse Canyon road is accessed off of SR-6 25 miles south of Price; the lower Price River road can be accessed off of SR-6 at the town of Woodside; the Hastings Road will access the east side of the Green River and can be found on the east side of the town of Green River, the Sego Canyon road is at the eastern boundary of the unit and is accessed in the town of Thompson.  Numerous small roads will access the mouths of Tushar, Coal, Horse, and Floy canyons.
